metadata.name: Bauhausstadt #150
metadata.description:
Bauhausstadt (Bauhaus City) is a series that draws direct inspiration from Ludwig Karl Hilberseimer's (September 14, 1885 ‚Äì May 6, 1967) work on city planning through a Bauhaus lens. Specifically, the series references his illustration from Bauhaus Magazine (Number 2, 1929) depicting a sustainable relationship between humans, industry, and nature. Hilberseimer proposed that this can be achieved through the construction of human habitation that ensures security for all people against disasters and crises.

This series explores Hilberseimer's use of "protective" architecture and repetition in his work, raising questions about the aesthetic and functional value of such an approach in urban planning. Through over 200 hand-drawn/coloured illustrations and a touch of randomness, the project visually poses this question and leaves it up to the viewer to decide its worth.

metadata.name: GENERATIVE GLASSES #305
metadata.description:
After 4 months of coding the Generative Glasses is ready! I gained a lot of experience along the way and I really liked the creation process.

I wrote an article in which I report on the creation process in more detail. It can be found at the bottom of the page for related articles.

üëì thousands of different outputs are possible
üë®‚Äçüíª only code
üé® 3D (#webGL #threejs) and 2D (#html5canvas) layers 
üé• animated
üñ±Ô∏è interactive (+controls for mobile)
üòé augmented reality view
üü• different previews: abstract view, product design view, and 2 other view
üñºÔ∏è save images from current view in 4k - 3 different aspect ratio
üìº save animation (from server side) on http://carco.hu

Compositions:

- There is an abstract view where the parts of the glasses are scattered
- There is a front-right view
- Front-left view
- Top view
- Product design view that converts to split screen
- Front view where the object falls apart and starts from the abstract view again

First, one of the 6 compositions comes in and the animation starts. The system randomly determines which composition should be the first in the line. This will also be the saved image that the fxhash system creates. 

If you don't click or touch anything, the animation will loop continuously. If you click into the area anywhere, the controller will appear and the animation will stop. Until you get to the next composition and the animation stops, the pause button flashes until now you can't press anything, all buttons are disabled. If the animation has stopped, the buttons are enabled again, and you can move the camera in 3D space by dragging. 

The controls have left and right arrows that can be used to step between compositions. The animation restarts with the play button.

There are also a few other buttons:

- There is a save button which is a floppy disk. A menu will then appear, offering to save images of different proportions, with the default aspect ratio generated by the program code at the top. (Opening in a new window is required to save an image)

- There is a camera icon that restores the original camera view. It is worth pressing this before saving.

There are options that are not available for all compositions, they only appear if they are enabled in current composition:

- Switch split screen to main camera view, and back (4 squares icon)
- Shows and hide Editing lines (pair of compasses)
- Shows and hide Callout notations (pencil and ruler)
- Shows AR view and stop it (cube icon) (Opening in a new window is required to AR view, more info below)

Keyboard controls:

Press ‚Äú5‚Äù to save image to default aspect ratio
Press ‚Äú6‚Äù to save image to square aspect ratio
Press ‚Äú7‚Äù to save image to portrait aspect ratio
Press ‚Äú8‚Äù to save image to landscape aspect ratio

(Opening in a new window is required to save an image)

Press ‚ÄúArrowDown‚Äù for restores the original camera view
Press ‚ÄúD‚Äù to switch to next composition
Press ‚ÄúA‚Äù to switch  to previous composition
Press ‚ÄúS‚Äù to start animation
Press ‚ÄúSpacebar‚Äù to switch to split screen (if it is available)
Press ‚Äú1‚Äù to hide/show Editing lines (if it is available)
Press ‚Äú2‚Äù to hide/show Callout notations (if it is available)
Press ‚Äú3‚Äù to hide/show AR view (Opening in a new window is required to AR view, more info below)

AR view

If you have a camera on your device, you can try out how such glasses would suit you. This function is not available for all compositions, so if you cannot find the cube icon, tab to the next composition and click on the cube icon. I created this function with the help of Tensorflow face landmark detection package. It's not perfect, there are delays, but it's good enough to try out the glasses.

More information on how were made Generative Glasses in the related article below.

Thank you for your attention! Thanks for the support! Thanks for the opportunity fxhash and genart community! I hope I was able to contribute to generative art with my work!

@C4RC0
carco.hu

metadata.name: Curtain #117
metadata.description:
The curtain of particles smears across the screen.

In live mode, tap the 's' key at any time to save a large version of it.

Enjoy!

metadata.name: tratti #54
metadata.description:
"tratti" is an Italian word that has many different meanings. When we started working on this piece, we wanted to create something that combines our traits ("tratti" in Italian).
We had this urge to channel the turbulent times we're living in now into this artwork using just lines ("tratti" in Italian).

We don't know what to do now, we're here, and that's all that matters. We're here for our families, our friends, and our community. Like everything in life, there are joyful times and challenging times. We must accept happiness as something that is not constant but that we feel at times (a "tratti" in Italian).

With "tratti", we want to send a message to every disheartened human being: "Stay strong and never let anyone or anything crush the hope in you. Joyful times are around the corner".

---- 

¬© 2022 ‚Äî Alessandro Fiore x Emanuele Pasin
LICENSE.md for detailed licensing info

metadata.name: Introspection #12
metadata.description:
Sketches of geometric shapes with scale symmetry.

"What does the mirror see when it looks in the mirror?"

--

- Live renderer best viewed in Chrome.
- Press "S" to export a standard resolution image.
- Press "P" to export an hi-res image.
- Press "G" to toggle the grain.

metadata.name: Glossolalia #76
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverse‚Ä¶ which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, it‚Äôs about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. It‚Äôs less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append ‚Äú&density=2‚Äù to the url to double the size, ‚Äú&density=3‚Äù to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append ‚Äú&grain=##‚Äù to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Action; System #8
metadata.description:
Action; system is an experimental study inspired by the work of Fran√ßois Morellet. Morellet was one of the founders of the Groupe de Recherche d'Art Visuel (GRAV), founded in the 60s. His work was often informed by systems, a set of rules that determine the artwork, reducing the artist's subjectivity to a minimum.

This work explores what happens when we let go of the strict rule set. Do we ever fully let go?

-----------------
This work was released for the 2023 fundraising exhibition Cure3, and all of the proceeds and 1% of royalties will go to Parkinson's research funds. You can find more information at https://cure3.co.uk/.

-----------------
Controls
- R: new randomized output (the chances of recovering one of these outputs are very slim, that's what the next control is for)
- E: high-res output
- Double click: fullscreen

While you see the eye of Horus, your artwork is loading.

------------------
Made with p5.js & glsl
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Paths That Join #44
metadata.description:
Connections, paths, flow. Paths That Join is about representing these ideas in a simple and poignant way. There is an invisible grid. Points are selected at random, serving as anchors, joints to a whole. Like the five pointed star that you could draw with a stroke of a pen without lifting the nib, the selected points are connected and their order is also random. An arc or a straight path connect any two points. The paths they make pulsate, spreading color into the surrounding pixels. Their arrangements criss-cross or, in other iterations, evoke glyphs and abstract park plans. Their directions are both circular and angular. They are paths that join. 

This piece is created with P5.js, p5Fbo by Adam Ferriss and ShadowCLJS for You Topia, an exhibition by VerticalCrypto Art and The NFT Gallery. 

Paths That Join is best viewed in Chrome at a resolution of 1920x1080.

metadata.name: MEGDAZ II #110
metadata.description:
Welcome to Megdaz II - one the most beautiful of all Central High Atlas area of Morocco.

I wanted to create an animated version of Megdaz - subtile movements but still interesting enough to observe the whole scene.

This artwork shows Megdaz as abstract town at different times and places:
- cafe terrace at night
- at the pool
- at the river
- before a mirror
- at the central park
- end of summer
- supper at Emmaus
- at the melting pot
- at the game

The canvas resolution is 4096x4096

--

Generative Art created by Michael Vogt (@neophob).

metadata.name: let me fall #397
metadata.description:
A study of form, empty spaces, panic attacks, asymmetry, tinnitus, chaos, and the never-ending journey to obtain imperfection. 

30 Matisse-inspired palettes.

2-6 ‚Äì increase resolution.

‚Äúf‚Äù ‚Äì add more noise to iteration at current resolution.
‚Äún‚Äù ‚Äì redraw at current resolution without noise.
‚Äús‚Äù ‚Äì save export.

Please be patient while drawing at higher resolutions, it can take quite a while.

Created with p5js.

metadata.name: Agave & Patchwork #18
metadata.description:
Agave & Patchwork
---------------
Controls:
Press 1-6 to change the scale of the canvas (1 = default, 2000px x 2000px, 6 = 12,000px x 12,000px)
S: Save output at current size
F: Toggle fullscreen
Add the url params x and y to set custom dimensions. For example, add &x=1500&y=500 for a 1500px x 500px image
---------------
Tyler Boswell (@teaboswell) 2023
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: Agave & Patchwork #41
metadata.description:
Agave & Patchwork
---------------
Controls:
Press 1-6 to change the scale of the canvas (1 = default, 2000px x 2000px, 6 = 12,000px x 12,000px)
S: Save output at current size
F: Toggle fullscreen
Add the url params x and y to set custom dimensions. For example, add &x=1500&y=500 for a 1500px x 500px image
---------------
Tyler Boswell (@teaboswell) 2023
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: September #184
metadata.description:
The Summer Ends
---------------
Controls:
S or double tap (mobile): Download image

A: Toggle loading animation (off by default to improve performance)

1-6: Modify scale (1 = default, 1500 x 2000px, 6 = maximum, 9000 x 12000px (performance intensive, will take a long time to render))
F: Fit to current screen size

T: Toggle grain and texture overlay
H: Toggle shape outlines

B: Cycle border sizes (0 -> 50 -> 75 -> 100 -> 150px)
C: Cycle border colors

I: Cycle visible layers

L: Toggle ‚Äúlive mode‚Äù. This mode will continuously redraw a new output every few seconds using the same base parameters as the original output, but with slight variations.

You can modify the x and y url parameters to set a custom size. Note that the image will change to fit the new size, but overall drawing style, colors, etc. will remain the same.
(For example, for a 1000x2000 image, add &x=1000&y=2000)
---------------
teaboswell 2022
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information
10% of primary sales will be donated to Girls Who Code (https://girlswhocode.com)

metadata.name: Dialect: Bold #75
metadata.description:
Dialect: Bold is the wild younger sibling of Dialect. As both Dialect collections are created using a string of text as the main input, "Bold" is also a play on the term used to denote the weight of a font. Many aesthetic decisions were made along the way to completing Dialect. Dialect: Bold is what would have happened had a different path been taken. Complimentary but different. Bold!

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save a high-resolution version of the image

Made in p5js
Created March 2023
By John Ryan

metadata.name: In Flow #100
metadata.description:
In Flow is the first in a series of four projects exploring flow fields, produced with 100% code in p5.js.  This one has a consistent gap between flow lines and a low noise resolution, producing a wispy effect that often looks like thread or felt.  Sometimes the background is a bit garish, which can be fun.  There's a good chance some texture will be added in the end, either mixing the colors and softening, or adding a fine paper texture.  It finishes off with a grain shader by Dave Pegurek found here: https://editor.p5js.org/davepagurek/sketches/m6p09ERHx

After opening, hit 2 - 5 for higher pixel densities, and 's' to save a png. Resizing the canvas reverts to pixel density 1.

Come visit my YouTube channel for generative art how-to videos: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJjYUJudUW67Tg79jtF_rpQ

metadata.name: Arranged mess #81
metadata.description: arranged mess is an animated work that use some algorithms. In this work, the algorithms along with the type of coloring and the placement of lines can create a kind of beautiful animation for you. hope you enjoy

metadata.name: GRAPHEME #250
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke. 
www.tribute-hwf.com

‚ÄúOne criterion for art involves the process used by the artist for shaping the work. In the special case of mathematically supported fine art, the artmaking process occurs in a mathematically defined operation that allows the generation and transformation of images, methods used for picture processing.‚Äù - Herbert W. Franke

I first came across Franke‚Äôs ‚ÄòOrnamental Alphabets‚Äô in his book ùòäùò∞ùòÆùò±ùò∂ùòµùò¶ùò≥ ùòéùò≥ùò¢ùò±ùò©ùò™ùò§ùò¥ - ùòäùò∞ùòÆùò±ùò∂ùòµùò¶ùò≥ ùòàùò≥ùòµ, and was intrigued with the idea of using a simple letterform to explore different generative image processing techniques. 

I‚Äôve used letters and writing in my work for a long time, both with letterpress printing and in my asemic poetry programs. With asemic writing, I generate unrecognizable letters to reference text, and here I use recognizable letterforms removed from their typical function as language signifiers. 

My goal with this project was to build as much texture and layering as possible by warping and collaging the letters together in various ways. The font I‚Äôm using is a design I made years ago to supplement my wood type collection for printing. I really enjoyed being able to bring that part of my past work into my generative art practice. 

Each image is composed of the letters found in the hash for that piece, divided into either vowels or consonants. The program builds on a technique I‚Äôve used before, where I generate an image to an off-screen canvas and then dive through the pixels to pull out the color and form I want to surface in the final image.

25% of the primary sales will be donated on-chain to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke. These funds will be used by ZKM Karlsruhe to digitize Franke‚Äôs 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. Any additional funds raised will be donated to the R√ºtgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.

- Press ‚ÄúR‚Äù to increase the pixel density and reload the image (this can be render intensive and will create a really large file suitable for printing)
- Press ‚ÄúS‚Äù to save a copy

Made with p5js
Artist: Sarah Ridgley
October, 2022

metadata.name: nearestNeighbor - 22.10.19-@-13.51.02.png #12
metadata.description:
This generative token is a randomly generated variation of the image file '22.10.19-@-13.51.02.png', which has been translated, cropped, and transformed at random. You can find the corresponding image-based NFT at the following url: https://objkt.com/asset/hicetnunc/816395
Morgan Higby-Flowers -2023

metadata.name: Klyft #828
metadata.description:
‚ÄúKlyft‚Äù is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft‚Äôs expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

¬∑ URL parameters ¬∑

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> ‚Äî See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> ‚Äî See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> ‚Äî View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true ‚Äî Save the piece as an image. 

record=true ‚Äî Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‚ÄòStokkendahl Dalgas‚Äô color scheme:

color=14&record=true

¬∑ Interactions ¬∑

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

¬∑ Accessibility ¬∑

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS‚Äô VoiceOver, and uses p5.js‚Äô describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

¬∑ Credits and license ¬∑

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).
